Name.BusinessNameLine1: AMERICAN CIVIL LIBERTIES UNION OF IOWA

IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: PROTECTION OF CIVIL LIBERTIES THROUGH PROGRAMS OF LEGISLATION AND PUBLIC EDUCATION.
IRS990.MissionDescription: TO SUPPORT THE CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES AND THE CONSTITUTION OF THE STATE OF IOWA; TO MAINTAIN THROUGHOUT THE UNITED STATES THE RIGHTS OF FREE SPEECH, FREE PRESS, FREE ASSEMBLAGE AND OTHER CIVIL RIGHTS AND TO TAKE ALL LEGITIMATE ACTION IN FURTHERANCE OF SUCH PURPOSES THROUGH A PROGRAM OF EDUCATION, UNDERSTANDING AND RESPECT FOR CIVIL LIBERTIES.
IRS990.Description: ACTIVE DEFENSE OF CIVIL LIBERTIES THROUGH LEGISLATIVE PROGRAM SERVICES.ACLU of Iowa Achievements:In regard to the U.S. Congress, the ACLU of Iowa on numerous occasions mobilized its members to contact their federal officials on various civil liberties issues, including reproductive freedom, immigration and educational reform, GLBT equality, paycheck fairness and sentencing reform.In the 2010 Iowa General Assembly, the ACLU of Iowa utilized a professional contract lobbyist to assist in legislative advocacy efforts at the Iowa Statehouse.Defending Free Speech. We were successful in defeating extreme legislative reactions to the "Citizens United" U.S. Supreme Court decision, which ruled that corporations must be allowed to engage in "independent" political campaign expenditures. We pointed out that most of America's citizens speak out through "corporations," such as the Sierra Club and the ACLU. Working for Open Meetings and Records. It has been widely reported that Iowans are having a difficult time utilizing Iowa"s open meetings and records law. We actively lobbied for Open Records and Open Meeting law reform, and supported legislation that would have strengthened those laws and their enforcement in Iowa. Protecting the Right of Due Process. The ACLU of Iowa supported changes to Iowa's laws regarding the issuance of permits to carry firearms to make the laws provide due process to persons equally in all 99 counties. Seeking to Legalize Medical Marijuana. The ACLU of Iowa continued to oppose inappropriately harsh and racially disproportionate drug laws. On the medical marijuana front, we filed a suit against the Iowa Pharmacy Board to reclassify cannabis for medical use, which not only led to statewide hearings on the issue, but ultimately helped that board make the decision to permit marijuana use by sick Iowans. Despite the Board's decision, the issue became stalled due to campaign politics, so more work is needed.Working for LGBT Equality: We continued to work with One Iowa and other groups to assure that the equality achieved with the Iowa Supreme Court decision Varnum v. Brien is not eroded or reversed by the Iowa legislature. Working for Justice Reform. We voiced concerns and recommended solutions to a wide variety of problems within our judicial and corrections systems.

Activity2.Description: ACTIVE DEFENSE OF CIVIL LIBERTIES THROUGH PUBLIC EDUCATION PROGRAM SERVICES.ACLU of Iowa Achievements:Defending Free Speech. The ACLU of Iowa has successfully defended the right of atheists to place ads on the sides of Des Moines buses, of ticket resellers to ply their trade, and of political party activists to distribute literature at street festivals. We also are closely monitoring a lawsuit recently filed by the Iowa Right to Life Committee challenging provisions in the law enacted over our objections. Protecting the Privacy and Free Speech Rights of Youth. We publicly condemned the strip search of school girls in Atlantic who were subjected to an illegal strip search for missing money. We later sued the Atlantic School District to learn what sanctions were imposed on the two school officials who made the decision to conduct the strip searches. News coverage of this lawsuit has helped educate the public on these important issues. Currently, we are also finishing up a "Student Rights in Iowa" handbook to distribute to Iowa youth, and will post this online for ready electronic access. Working for Open Meetings and Records. It has been widely reported that Iowans are having a difficult time utilizing Iowa's open meetings and records law. We have actively lobbied for Open Records and Open Meeting law reform. After the Iowa House and Senate reached an impasse on reform in this area, we began working on our own "Open Government Project" to provide more assistance to individuals who have been stonewalled or stymied in their efforts to force open government. Protecting the Rights of Parents and Families. The ACLU has publicly condemned or even challenged other attempts to regulate youth behavior as an intrusion on the rights of parents. Our challenge to Davenport's "Parental Responsibility" ordinance, which punishes parents whenever their children are stopped by police, raises significant issues of due process and family autonomy. We have also publicly commented on student dress codes and issues of free speech on campus. Seeking to Legalize Medical Marijuana. On the medical marijuana front, we have often spoken to the public about our lawsuit against the Iowa Pharmacy Board to reclassify cannabis for medical use, which not only led to statewide hearings on the issue, but ultimately helped that board make the decision to permit marijuana use by sick Iowans. Working for LGBT Equality: We continue to work with One Iowa and other groups to assure that the equality achieved with the Iowa Supreme Court decision Varnum v. Brien is not eroded or reversed. Balancing National Security with Freedom. Our opposition to the misdirection of anti-terrorism resources to infiltrate and investigate peace groups remained a core concern. ACLU of Iowa staff were quoted on several occasions expressing grave concerns regarding what appear to be unnecessary or unjustified surveillance tactics by the FBI and other federal agencies. Immigration. The ACLU of Iowa publicly argued for better due process and fairness in the application and enforcement of federal immigration law in Iowa. Working for Justice Reform. We were relentless in voicing concerns and recommending solutions to a wide variety of problems within our judicial and corrections systems. Affiliate staff members continued their service on several state panels and task forces, including issues of juvenile justice, disproportionate minority confinement, and the treatment and rehabilitation of sex offenders.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Intended Use of Endowment Funds:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: THE ORGANIZATION RECEIVED A $10,000 CONTRIBUTION THAT IS RESTRICTED FOR FUNDING THE COSTS OF AN ANNUAL SCHOLARSHIP PROGRAM.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 6
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: THE ACLU OF IOWA IS A MEMBERSHIP ORGANIZATION OF APPROXIMATELY 3,000 MEMBERS RESIDING IN THE STATE OF IOWA.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 7a
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The 21 At-large members of the board of directors are elected by ballots mailed annually to Iowa members of the organization. The directors serve 3 year terms. Chapter representatives to the state board of directors are elected by the local chapters. From the By Laws: Section 4. Elections. Members of the Board of Directors shall be members of the American Civil Liberties Union of Iowa and shall be nominated and elected as follows: A. The President shall appoint, subsequent to the annual meeting each year, a standing nominating committee to solicit and select candidates for places on the Board becoming vacant the following year. The nominating committee shall consist of five (5) members of whom no more than three (3) shall be Board members. The report of the nominating committee shall be given to the Board at its last board meeting of the calendar year. For purposes of an annual ballot, the nominating committee shall submit more nominees than the number of vacancies to be filled. B. Additional nominations may be made by petition of any five (5) members, provided there is attached to such petition a signed statement expressing the nominees willingness to serve if elected, any such petition to be filed with the chairperson of the nominating committee, or the Executive Director, no later than 30 days before election ballots are mailed to members. C. Election of Directors shall be conducted by balloting of the membership of the American Civil Liberties Union of Iowa. Ballots with the names of nominees qualifying under subsection .1 or .2 of this section shall be submitted to the membership in sufficient time so that newly- elected Board members can be seated when the terms of their predecessors expire. The Board of Directors may adopt other procedures for the conduct of the balloting.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: THE FORM 990 AND SUPPORTING SCHEDULES IS DRAFTED BY A PAID PREPARER AND REVIEWED WITH THE EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR. THE FORM IS THEN REVIEWED IN A JOINT MEETING OF THE MEMBERS OF THE FINANCE/AUDIT COMMITTEE WITH THE PAID PREPARER AND EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR. A COPY OF THE FORM 990 IS THEN MAILED TO THE DIRECTORS PRIOR TO FILING WITH THE INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Annually at its March board meeting, all directors of the organization are required to review our conflict of interest policy and complete a conflict of interest form on which they disclose all potential conflicts as defined in our policy. Directors are reminded that they have an obligation to inform the organization if any conflicts arise during their service on the board.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15a
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: In addition to the process described below, it has been the practice of the ACLU of Iowa to have comparable survey salary data from other ACLU affiliates presented to the executive committee during the process of determining salaries. In addition, contemporaneous notes and minutes of these proceedings have been kept and maintained in our files. This is from the ACLU of Iowa Personnel Policy: Salary and Benefits Review. No later than five days after the end of the eleventh month of the ACLU-IA fiscal year, the executive director shall identify for the executive committee a lump sum of funds he or she recommends be earmarked for the enhancement of the salaries of all staff, including the executive director. This recommendation shall be divided into two categories: 1) Cost of Living Adjustments (COLA) and 2) Merit Adjustments. For informational purposes only, the recommendation shall also include a final dollar amount that is larger than the sum of these categories. This final dollar amount shall reflect payroll line item expenses that are directly related to, and affected by, salary amounts, thus giving a more accurate picture of the budgetary impact of the salary adjustments being considered. Finally, the recommendation shall include any proposed changes to the ACLU-IA Personnel Policy, including changes in staff benefits. After receiving the recommendation, the executive committee shall meet and first identify that portion of each category which it feels should go towards compensation of the executive director. The executive director shall then inform the executive committee whether he or she continues to stand by his or her original lump sum recommendation, or whether he or she wishes to propose an adjustment. The executive committee will then determine the lump sum amount for each category. Finally, the executive committee shall determine what, if any, changes are to be made to the ACLU-IA Personnel Policy, including changes in staff benefits. As soon as is practicable after this initial stage, the executive director shall present the executive committee with two more items. He or she shall first report to the executive committee the salaries he or she arrived at for each staff person. After the executive committee receives this information, the executive director shall present it with a proposed combined budget for the ACLU-IA/ ACLU-IAF. The executive committee shall then make a budget recommendation to the full board, which shall take up the proposal at the last meeting of the fiscal year.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: UPON RECEIPT OF A WRITTEN REQUEST, WITHIN FIVE BUSINESS DAYS, THE ORGANIZATION WILL PROVIDE COPIES OF THEIR GOVERNING DOCUMENTS, CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY AND AUDITED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS. REQUESTS MAY BE SENT TO: ACLU-IA, 505 FIFTH AVENUE, STE. 901, DES MOINES, IA 50309. REQUESTS MAY ALSO BE SENT THROUGH THE ORGANIZATION'S WEB SITE, WWW.ACLU-IA.ORG. CLICK ON "CONTACT US". REQUESTS MUST PROVIDE A RETURN POSTAL ADDRESS OR EMAIL ADDRESS.
THE ORGANIZATION'S FINANCE/AUDIT COMMITTEE IS RESPONSIBLE FOR OVERSIGHT OF THE ANNUAL AUDIT AND SELECTION OF THE INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTANT. THE PROCESS HAS NOT CHANGED FROM THE PRIOR YEAR.
